organizations: University of the Sacred Heart, Tokyo
roles: bachelor's degree in English Literature graduate
supporting_quotes: She stayed in Japan during World War II and after the war, she graduated from the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo with a bachelor's degree in English Literature.

organizations: Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service
roles: master's degree in International Relations graduate
supporting_quotes: she dared to study at Georgetown University and its Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service, earning a master's degree in International Relations.
She was awarded a PhD in Political Science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1963, after she completed a dissertation on the politics behind the foundation of Manchukuo.
In 1965, she became Lecturer at International Christian University in Tokyo.

organizations: Permanent Mission of Japan to the United Nations
supporting_quotes: Ogata was appointed to Japan's UN mission in 1968, on the recommendation of Fusae Ichikawa
Ogata represented Japan at several sessions of the UN General Assembly in 1970.

organizations: Permanent Mission of Japan to the United Nations
roles: Chair of the UNICEF Executive Board
supporting_quotes: she served from 1978 to 1979 as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary for the permanent mission of Japan to the UN, and as Chair of the UNICEF Executive Board.

roles: Dean of the Faculty of Foreign Studies
supporting_quotes: After 1980, she taught international politics at Sophia University in Tokyo as a professor and later became Dean of the Faculty of Foreign Studies until her departure to join the UNHCR in 1991.

organizations: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
roles: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
supporting_quotes: In 1990, she was appointed as head of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). She was the first woman to be appointed as a head of the UNHCR.
She was re-elected twice (in November 1993 and in September 1998), and served, over a decade, until 2001.

time_markers: launched at end of UNHCR tenure
supporting_quotes: In December 2000, and coinciding with the end of her second term at the High Commission at UNHCR, as well as the 50th anniversary of the agency, Ogata announced the launch of RET International in Geneva, Switzerland.
After UNHCR leader, in 2001, she became co-chairperson of UN Human Security Commission.

roles: Special Representative of Prime Minister of Japan on Reconstruction Assistance to Afghanistan
supporting_quotes: In 2001, after the September 11 attacks, she was appointed as Special Representative of Prime Minister of Japan on Reconstruction Assistance to Afghanistan.
the Japanese government appointed her as President of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) on 1 October 2003.
She continued to work as president of JICA for more than two terms (over eight years), retiring in April 2012

organizations: Advisory Council on the Imperial House Law
supporting_quotes: She was a member of The Advisory Council on the Imperial House Law on 27 November 2014.
The council met 17 times from 25 January 2005 to discuss the Japanese succession controversy and the Imperial Household Act.
She also served as Advisor of the Executive Committee of the Japan Model United Nations (JMUN).
Ogata was involved in the Sergio Vieira de Mello Foundation.
was a Japanese academic, diplomat, author, administrator, and professor emerita at the Roman Catholic Sophia University.
